text: What was the to have that we use to go in the past?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, I have cancelled?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we said that the version of the verb that you get after haber, you can use it like an adjective as well in Spanish, just as we do in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, in English we could say, it's cancelled.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We use the same version, cancelled, that comes after haber.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we can do the same in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, it is cancelled?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And I remind you that the adjectives that we form in this way tend to go with estar, only with a few exceptions that are more flexible.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if we meant la fiesta, the party?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Fiesta, by the way, is actually related to festival, festivity.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can see the E splitting between festival and fiesta.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To complicate in Spanish, what's complication?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you want to say, it has got complicated.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think you would say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It has complicated itself, we would say.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you can say, it is complicated.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Actually, with this one, you can use either.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It tends to be a tendency to go with estar, with these types of adjectives, but with complicado, you could say either.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Depending on what you are talking about, you might feel more drawn to one or to the other, but most of the time, they're going to be interchangeable here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can also make structures like should have, could have, with this other.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, should, we take it from the verb to owe, which also we use like must, and it's related to English debt.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, deber is to owe or must, and if you say would owe, you get should.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, I should?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, now we can say, I should have cancelled, and this have is to have.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Where else could that lo go there?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we take to be able, and we say would be able to get this could, this could that refers to future.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, what is to be able related to power?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, I would be able or I could?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you could say something like, I could have gone.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what was gone, the version of to go after haber?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, after haber, any version of haber, whether it's the to form, haber, whether it's habría, any version of haber, is going to have hado or ido with the following verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But, some verbs are irregular, and they don't form their version after haber in this way.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, to break, related to rupture in English, was romper.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, this after haber is not rompido.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, I have broken it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if you want to say, it has broken?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you had just said, a roto, I would understand he, she, it, or you, formal, has or have broken, and I would be waiting to hear what was broken.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we have roto instead of rompido, let's say.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Roto is the version of romper after haber, which means it will also count for the adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, if you want to say, it is broken, how would you say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if it was a feminine thing?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the version after haber is not morido, it's muerto.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say he has died?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And with morir, you can hear it with se or without se.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There's not really a lot of difference.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sometimes the se doesn't actually make a lot of difference.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Ha muerto, se ha muerto, you hear both.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if you want to say he is dead, how do you think you would say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You mean if it's estar or ser?
speaker: Speaker 2

text: We know that this type of adjective tends to go with...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But I could see why this specific one could also go with ser under certain circumstances.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: So, some of these adjectives we form in this way can go with ser, but this one can't.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, firstly, how would that be?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, it could go with ser and estar, but muerto can't.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe it's not just because there are these type of adjectives that dead will go with estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe it is about the way Spanish perceives the world.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To be dead is a state that the soul goes through, let's say.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You don't know what is the perception behind that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or if it's just going with estar because it's one of these adjectives.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, they're interesting points to think about and thinking about those points helps your memory.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Even if you're just looking out of interest and not coming to any conclusions.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I'm dead?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you can use this to mean tired.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is quite common in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you're really tired, you can say I'm dead.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can say also I die myself.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In all different kinds of circumstances.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When something's really funny, when you can't believe something.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In many different circumstances you could use that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Let's see how it would sound.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, to die, morir, I die myself, making this reflexive structure.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's irregular, so the muer is going to come in.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: So, you will hear this all the time in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe from embarrassment, maybe from laughter, maybe from disbelief.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To open in Spanish is abrir.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if you want to say I have opened it, you say lo he abierto.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we don't have abrido, after haber we have abierto.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Good that you're thinking about that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say it is open?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say they are open?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And to make or to do.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: These two verbs are quite irregular in most places.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We will pay them a little more attention later.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, decir, to say or to tell, and hacer, to do and to make, are irregular after haber.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Decir becomes dicho, and hacer becomes hecho, which is why they're nice to say together, because they both have this CH sound.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Decir becomes dicho, and hacer becomes hecho.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say I have said it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what if you wanted to say I have told him?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But what we want here is not him.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What we want here is to him.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Interestingly, dicho is also a noun.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said that some version of the verb can form the noun.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sometimes it's the true form, sometimes it's the I form, sometimes it's the he, she, it form.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say I have done it, or I have made it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Of course, we can put the lo there because we have haber in the true form.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Debería haberlo hecho, or lo debería haber hecho.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You should have done it, informally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say it is done?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might also see this used like hecho en China, made in China, or hecho en España, made in Spain.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You will see this on products.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It should be a nice reminder.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, hecho as an adjective, made or done.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But it can also be a noun.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And it's actually connected to the word fact.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Even though they look so different.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There is, in Spanish and English, what we can call a kind of grey area between Hs and Fs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because in a phonetic change that occurred in Spanish, many Fs became silent Hs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Just as hecho is from hacer, fact is from to do.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, fair, like in French, if you know some French, is to do.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And fact is related to fair, just as hecho is related to hacer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we can find some other connections between this F and this silent H.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, in English we have fable.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And from there we see the relation with hablar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Which is the same root as huir.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or to run away, in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or with an A on the end for hermana.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And there we see the connection with fraternal.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Even within Spanish you can see this phenomenon of the Hs and the Fs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, you have iron, which is hierro.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then you get ferrocarril, which means railways.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you know that the F became a silent H.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And that the E split into IE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can see the connection between hierro and ferrocarril.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then you have hondo, which means deep.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So hondo is the fundo bit of profundo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then humo, H-U-M-O, is smoke.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So there is some interesting things we can find between English and Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Also you can look out for some connections with other letters.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You will find other pairs of letters.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Like this, for example, Ws and Gs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You get war in English and guerra in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: William in English and Guillermo in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is an interesting thing to keep an eye out for.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And of course, in this way, aid your memory.
speaker: Speaker 1
